Dr. Ames resembles the practical
business man; he is smooth-shaven
and vigorous. His speech is clipped,
his manner energetic and enthusiastic. He has an air of competence and
decisiveness about him that supplements the quick reasoning of that analytical mind, which unhesitatingly
gets to the heart of most of his problems. His fair-mindedness is reflected
in his "open door policy to students"
and in his abhorrence for everything
that smacks of "politics and pull."
The finest traits of Dr. Ames are
his broadmindedness and comprehensieness in understanding the relationships between men. He is quick to see
another's point of view and careful
not to wound a person's sensitiveness.
His understanding of human nature
prevents him from assuming an air
of condescension toward younger men.
He can still look back on his own
youth and sympathize with the feelings of today's younger generation.
These are the qualities that have endeared him to the students.
Much of the personality of Dr.
Ames is expressed in his speeches and
interviews. They give us a broad conception of his well-founded opinions.

Dr. Ames resembles the practical
business man; he is smooth-shaven
and vigorous. His speech is clipped,
his manner energetic and enthusiastic. He has an air of competence and
decisiveness about him that supplements the quick reasoning of that analytical mind, which unhesitatingly
gets to the heart of most of his problems. His fair-mindedness is reflected
in his "open door policy to students"
and in his abhorrence for everything
that smacks of "politics and pull."
The finest traits of Dr. Ames are
his broadmindedness and comprehensieness in understanding the relationships between men. He is quick to see
another's point of view and careful
not to wound a person's sensitiveness.
His understanding of human nature
prevents him from assuming an air
of condescension toward younger men.
He can still look back on his own
youth and sympathize with the feelings of today's younger generation.
These are the qualities that have endeared him to the students.
Much of the personality of Dr.
Ames is expressed in his speeches and
interviews. They give us a broad conception of his well-founded opinions.
First he believes that old ideas should

reason I feel like reserving my own
to his consideration in one particular
aspect: as a reader of books in general, and as an encourager of general reading.
I remember once hearing Dr. Ames
declare that the real test of a man's
education is what he does with his
leisure. From his own wide knowledge of all sorts of books outside of
his special field, one might suppose

book, old or recent, mentioned in his
presence, and have heard him show
unmistakable—faimmediate—and
miliarity with its contents. How does
he do it? I should suggest that he
spends both leisure and working
hours in reading, but what he has
done in travel, aviation, science, and
administration renders this theory
doubtful.

when education is mentioned. Apparently they consider it the technique
of knowledge transfusion while the
victim is in a proper state of narcosis or anesthesia. Dr. Ames does

and happily to enjoy it in his welldeserved leisure!
